name: PROGRESA/Oportunidades/Prospera
nameLocal: Programa de Educación, Salud y Alimentación
summaryShort: Mexico's pioneering conditional cash transfer program that provided payments to poor families conditional on children's school attendance and health check-ups.
summaryLong: PROGRESA (later renamed Oportunidades and then Prospera) was Mexico's flagship anti-poverty program and one of the world's first large-scale conditional cash transfer programs. The program provided cash transfers to poor rural and urban families conditional on children attending school regularly and family members obtaining preventive health care. At its peak, the program reached approximately 6 million families (about 25% of Mexico's population). The program was phased out in 2018 and replaced by different social programs.
objectives: Increase school enrollment and attendance among poor children
Improve health outcomes through preventive care
Reduce poverty through direct cash transfers
Break the intergenerational transmission of poverty
mechanisms: The program provided direct cash transfers to mothers in poor households, conditional on children's school attendance (85% minimum) and regular health check-ups. Transfer amounts increased with grade level and were higher for girls in secondary school to address gender gaps. The program also provided nutritional supplements for children and pregnant/lactating women.
coverage: 6 million families at peak (approximately 25% of Mexican population)
impactSummary: Multiple rigorous evaluations found significant positive effects on education outcomes. The program increased enrollment by 14 percentage points for 14-year-old boys, with overall schooling increases of 1.3 years. Effects on test scores were more modest but positive. The program became a model for CCT programs worldwide.

evaluations.title: School subsidies for the poor: evaluating the Mexican Progresa poverty program
evaluations.keyFinding: Enrollment increased by 14 percentage points for boys and 9 percentage points for girls at the secondary level.

evaluations.authors: Parker, Susan W. & Todd, Petra E.
evaluations.title: Conditional Cash Transfers: The Case of Progresa/Oportunidades
evaluations.keyFinding: Long-term impacts show 1.3 additional years of schooling and improvements in labor market outcomes.

keyReferences.title: Progress Against Poverty: Sustaining Mexico's Progresa-Oportunidades Program

name: Bolsa Família
summaryShort: Brazil's flagship conditional cash transfer program providing monthly payments to poor families conditional on children's school attendance and health requirements.
summaryLong: Bolsa Família is Brazil's largest social assistance program, created in 2003 by unifying several pre-existing transfer programs. It provides monthly cash transfers to poor families (income below R$218 per capita) conditional on children's school attendance (minimum 85% for ages 6-15, 75% for ages 16-17) and health check-ups. The program reaches approximately 14 million families (about 50 million people) and is credited with significant reductions in poverty and inequality in Brazil.
objectives: Break the cycle of intergenerational poverty
mechanisms: Monthly cash transfers to families living below the poverty line, conditional on children attending school and complying with health requirements including vaccinations and prenatal care. Benefits vary by family composition and income level.
impactSummary: Multiple studies show positive effects on school enrollment and attendance, particularly in the early grades. The program increased enrollment by 5.5% for grades 1-4 and reduced dropout by 0.5 percentage points. Effects on learning outcomes are more mixed.

evaluations.title: The impact of the Bolsa Escola/Familia conditional cash transfer program on enrollment, dropout rates and grade promotion in Brazil
evaluations.keyFinding: Enrollment increased by 5.5% in grades 1-4, with larger effects for children from poorer households.

keyReferences.title: The Nuts and Bolts of Brazil's Bolsa Família Program
keyReferences.source: World Bank Social Protection Discussion Paper

name: Familias en Acción
summaryShort: Colombia's main conditional cash transfer program providing subsidies to poor families for nutrition, education, and health.
summaryLong: Familias en Acción is Colombia's largest social program, launched in 2001 as part of the country's response to the economic crisis. The program provides cash transfers to poor families conditional on children's school attendance and regular health check-ups. It has expanded significantly since its inception and now covers both rural and urban areas. The program includes education grants for children ages 7-17 and nutrition grants for children under 7.
objectives: Protect and promote human capital formation among poor children
mechanisms: Bi-monthly cash transfers to mothers in eligible households. Education subsidies conditional on 80% school attendance. Separate nutrition grants for young children conditional on health check-ups. Transfer amounts vary by age and education level.
impactSummary: Rigorous evaluations show positive effects on school enrollment, reduced child labor, and improved nutritional outcomes. The program significantly increased secondary school attendance and reduced the probability of children working.

keyOutcomes.effect: Significant reduction, especially in rural areas

evaluations.title: Child Education and Work Choices in the Presence of a Conditional Cash Transfer Programme in Rural Colombia
evaluations.keyFinding: The program increased secondary enrollment by 5-7 percentage points and significantly reduced child labor in rural areas.

keyReferences.title: Evaluación de Impacto de Familias en Acción

name: Jornada Escolar Completa
summaryShort: Chile's full-school-day reform that extended instructional time from half-day to full-day sessions, requiring massive infrastructure investment.
summaryLong: The Jornada Escolar Completa (JEC) was a major education reform in Chile that extended the school day from approximately 5 hours to 8 hours for primary and secondary students. Launched in 1997, the reform required significant infrastructure investment to accommodate full-day schedules. By 2010, the vast majority of subsidized schools had adopted the extended day. The reform aimed to improve educational quality and provide more equitable learning opportunities, particularly for disadvantaged students who lacked educational support at home.
objectives: Increase instructional time and learning opportunities
Provide more equitable access to education
Reduce educational gaps between socioeconomic groups
mechanisms: Schools extended their daily schedule from half-day (approximately 5 hours) to full-day (approximately 8 hours). The reform included substantial government investment in school infrastructure (new classrooms, dining facilities) and increased per-student subsidies for participating schools.
coverage: Over 90% of subsidized schools (approximately 2.5 million students)
impactSummary: Long-term studies show significant positive effects on adult outcomes. Students exposed to JEC had 10% higher labor income as adults and 8.6% higher intergenerational mobility. Effects on test scores were more modest but positive for disadvantaged students.

evaluations.title: The Effects of the Full-day School Program on Adult Labor Market Outcomes
evaluations.keyFinding: Full exposure to JEC increased adult earnings by approximately 10%.

evaluations.title: Does lengthening the school day increase students' academic achievement?
evaluations.keyFinding: Test score effects were modest overall but larger for rural students and those from lower socioeconomic backgrounds.

keyReferences.title: La reforma educacional chilena

name: Plan Ceibal
nameLocal: Conectividad Educativa de Informática Básica para el Aprendizaje en Línea
summaryShort: Uruguay's pioneering one-laptop-per-child program providing free laptops and internet connectivity to all public school students and teachers.
summaryLong: Plan Ceibal is Uruguay's implementation of the One Laptop Per Child (OLPC) initiative, making Uruguay the first country to provide a laptop to every primary school student and teacher in public schools. Launched in 2007, the program has distributed over 1 million devices and provides free internet connectivity in schools and public spaces. Beyond hardware distribution, the program includes teacher training, educational content development, and platforms for remote learning.
objectives: Reduce the digital divide in education
Provide universal access to information technology
mechanisms: Distribution of free laptops to all students and teachers in public schools. Provision of internet connectivity in schools and public spaces. Development of educational software and content. Teacher training in technology integration. Remote learning platforms and adaptive learning tools.
coverage: All public school students and teachers (approximately 700,000 devices distributed)
impactSummary: Evaluations show significant success in reducing the digital divide, with increased computer access at home and improved digital literacy. However, effects on traditional academic outcomes (test scores) have been limited. The program has been more successful in promoting technology access than improving learning outcomes.

keyOutcomes.effect: Significant increase, especially among low-income students

evaluations.title: The Impact of a One Laptop per Child Program on Learning: Evidence from Uruguay
evaluations.keyFinding: No significant effects on math or reading test scores, but significant reduction in the digital divide.

keyReferences.title: Plan Ceibal: Scaling Up Educational Innovation

name: School Voucher System
summaryShort: Chile's nationwide school voucher system allowing families to choose between public and private subsidized schools, with per-student funding following students.
summaryLong: Chile implemented one of the world's most comprehensive school voucher systems in 1981, creating a market-based education system where public and private subsidized schools compete for students. All schools receive per-student subsidies, and families can choose any participating school. The system led to significant growth in the private subsidized sector. However, concerns about increasing socioeconomic segregation led to reforms including the 2008 Preferential School Subsidy (SEP) and the 2015 Inclusion Law.
objectives: Expand private sector participation in education
mechanisms: Universal voucher system where funding follows students. Schools (public and private subsidized) receive per-student subsidies. Families can freely choose schools. Private schools could charge additional fees (co-payment) until recent reforms restricted this practice.
coverage: Approximately 90% of students attend voucher-funded schools
impactSummary: Extensive research shows mixed effects. While competition may have improved some efficiency metrics, the system significantly increased socioeconomic segregation in schools. Recent reforms (SEP, Inclusion Law) have aimed to address equity concerns with some positive early results.

keyOutcomes.effect: Modest improvements in private subsidized sector

evaluations.title: The effects of generalized school choice on achievement and stratification: Evidence from Chile's voucher program
evaluations.keyFinding: No evidence that competition improved average test scores; significant sorting of students across schools.

keyReferences.title: The impact of school choice and public policy on segregation: Evidence from Chile

name: Affirmative Action Quotas
summaryShort: Brazil's federal law mandating that public universities reserve 50% of seats for students from public high schools, with sub-quotas for low-income, Black, mixed-race, and indigenous students.
summaryLong: Brazil's quota law (Lei de Cotas, Law 12.711/2012) requires all federal universities and technical institutes to reserve 50% of admissions for students who completed high school in public institutions. Within this 50%, sub-quotas apply for low-income students and for Black, mixed-race (pardo), and indigenous students in proportion to state demographics. The policy was implemented gradually between 2012 and 2016 and has significantly increased diversity in higher education.
objectives: Increase access to higher education for underrepresented groups
Reduce racial and socioeconomic inequalities in education
mechanisms: Mandatory reservation of 50% of seats at federal universities for public high school graduates. Within this quota, half (25% of total) reserved for low-income students. Racial quotas (Black, mixed-race, indigenous) applied proportionally to state demographics within each category.
coverage: 63 federal universities and 38 federal institutes (over 1 million quota-admitted students)
impactSummary: Research shows quota students perform similarly to or better than non-quota peers after initial semesters. Quota students close about 50% of the initial GPA gap by graduation. Dropout rates are only slightly higher for quota students. The policy has substantially increased diversity in universities.

keyOutcomes.effect: Quota students close ~50% of initial gap by graduation
Similar rates for quota and non-quota students

evaluations.title: Affirmative Action and the Choice of Professions
evaluations.keyFinding: Quota students close about 50% of the initial GPA gap by graduation and enter more competitive fields.

keyReferences.title: Using Brazil's Racial Continuum to Examine the Short-Term Effects of Affirmative Action in Higher Education

name: Ser Pilo Paga
summaryShort: Colombia's merit-based scholarship program providing full tuition and living stipends for high-achieving, low-income students to attend accredited universities.
summaryLong: Ser Pilo Paga ('It Pays to Be Smart') was a Colombian government program providing full scholarships for high-achieving students from low-income families to attend any accredited university. Students who scored in the top 10% on the national exam (Saber 11) and came from families in the lowest socioeconomic strata received full tuition coverage plus living stipends. The program enrolled about 40,000 students before being replaced by Generación E in 2019.
objectives: Expand access to quality higher education for low-income students
Reward academic merit among disadvantaged students
Reduce socioeconomic barriers to university education
mechanisms: Merit-based scholarships covering full tuition at any accredited university (public or private) plus living stipends. Students must maintain satisfactory academic progress. Loans convert to scholarships upon graduation.
impactSummary: Rigorous evaluation shows the program significantly reduced dropout rates and improved academic outcomes. SPP students had dropout rates of 4.9% compared to 10.9% for similar peers. The program's Marginal Value of Public Funds (MVPF) was estimated at 4.8-5.6, indicating high cost-effectiveness.

keyOutcomes.effect: +33 percentage points enrollment in high-quality universities

evaluations.title: Upstream and Downstream Impacts of College Merit-Based Financial Aid for Low-Income Students
evaluations.keyFinding: SPP increased enrollment in high-quality universities by 33 percentage points and reduced dropout to 4.9%.

keyReferences.title: Is 'Ser Pilo Paga' Being Well Spent?
keyReferences.source: Universidad de los Andes Working Paper

name: Chile Crece Contigo
summaryShort: Chile's comprehensive early childhood development system providing universal services from pregnancy through age 4, with enhanced support for vulnerable families.
summaryLong: Chile Crece Contigo is a comprehensive intersectoral social protection system for early childhood that accompanies children from gestation through preschool. The program provides universal services through the public health system (prenatal care, developmental screenings) with additional targeted support for vulnerable families, including priority access to childcare, home visits, and educational materials. It represents a systematic approach to early childhood development as a national priority.
objectives: Ensure optimal development for all children from birth
Reduce developmental inequalities from the earliest ages
Enable mothers' participation in the labor force
mechanisms: Universal developmental support through health system. Priority access to publicly funded childcare (sala cuna and jardín infantil) for working mothers from lower income quintiles. Home visiting programs for at-risk families. Educational materials and parenting support. Developmental screening and early intervention.
coverage: Universal for children in public health system; targeted services reach most vulnerable 60%
impactSummary: Evaluations show significant expansion in childcare coverage (130% increase) and positive effects on child development and maternal employment. The program increased female labor force participation by 14 percentage points among eligible mothers.

evaluations.title: The Impact of Chile Crece Contigo (ChCC) on Child Development and Daycare Choices
evaluations.keyFinding: Program improved cognitive and socio-emotional development, with largest effects for most disadvantaged children.

keyReferences.title: Chile Crece Contigo: el desafío de la protección social a la infancia

name: National School Feeding Program
summaryShort: Brazil's national school feeding program, one of the world's largest, providing free meals to all public school students with mandated local food procurement.
summaryLong: PNAE is one of the oldest and largest school feeding programs in the world, providing free meals to all students in Brazil's public education system. Since 2009, the program mandates that at least 30% of food must be purchased from local family farmers, creating a link between school nutrition and local agricultural development. The program covers approximately 45 million students across all grades in public schools.
objectives: Ensure food security for all public school students
Improve nutritional status and school attendance
Support local family farming through procurement
mechanisms: Federal government transfers funds to states and municipalities for school meal provision. Schools must purchase at least 30% of food from local family farms. Menu planning follows national nutritional guidelines. Universal coverage for all public school students.
impactSummary: Studies show positive effects on school attendance and reduced hunger. The local procurement requirement has benefited family farmers. Nutritional impacts vary by implementation quality. Limited rigorous evidence on learning outcomes.

evaluations.title: The State of School Feeding Worldwide
evaluations.keyFinding: Brazil's PNAE serves as a global model for linking school feeding with local agricultural development.

keyReferences.title: Programa Nacional de Alimentação Escolar - Relatório de Gestão
keyReferences.source: Fundo Nacional de Desenvolvimento da Educação

name: Juntos
nameLocal: Programa Nacional de Apoyo Directo a los Más Pobres
summaryShort: Peru's conditional cash transfer program providing monthly payments to extremely poor families conditional on children's school attendance and health requirements.
summaryLong: Juntos is Peru's main conditional cash transfer program, targeting extremely poor households in rural areas. The program provides a monthly cash transfer of 200 soles (approximately $60) to mothers, conditional on children's school attendance (85% minimum) and compliance with health check-ups for children and prenatal care for pregnant women. The program prioritizes rural and indigenous communities and operates in all 24 departments of Peru.
objectives: Reduce poverty and extreme poverty in rural areas
mechanisms: Bi-monthly cash transfers to mothers in extremely poor households. Conditionalities include minimum 85% school attendance and regular health check-ups. Targeting based on household poverty assessment. Priority to rural and indigenous communities.
impactSummary: Evaluations show positive effects on school enrollment, health service utilization, and food consumption. Effects on educational outcomes beyond enrollment are more limited. The program has been credited with poverty reduction in rural areas.

evaluations.title: 5 Years in Juntos: New Evidence on the Program's Short and Long-Term Impacts
evaluations.keyFinding: Positive effects on school enrollment, health service use, and consumption, but limited effects on learning outcomes.

keyReferences.title: Programa Nacional de Apoyo Directo a los Más Pobres - JUNTOS
keyReferences.source: Ministerio de Desarrollo e Inclusión Social

name: Asignación Universal por Hijo
summaryShort: Argentina's universal child allowance providing monthly payments to informal workers' families conditional on school attendance and health requirements.
summaryLong: The Asignación Universal por Hijo (Universal Child Allowance) extends Argentina's family allowance system to children of unemployed workers, informal workers, and domestic workers. The program provides monthly payments per child (up to 5 children) conditional on school attendance and vaccination compliance. It covers approximately 4 million children and represents one of the largest social protection programs in Argentina.
objectives: Extend social protection to informal sector workers
mechanisms: Monthly cash transfer per child (up to 5) to families in informal employment or unemployed. 80% paid monthly, 20% upon proof of school attendance and health compliance. Benefits indexed to inflation.
impactSummary: Studies show modest positive effects on school attendance and enrollment, particularly at the secondary level. The program reduced school dropout and improved attendance rates by approximately 1.3 percentage points.

keyOutcomes.effect: Positive effect, especially for poorest quintile

evaluations.title: The Impact of a Conditional Cash Transfer on Education: The Universal Child Allowance in Argentina
evaluations.keyFinding: AUH increased school attendance by 1.3 percentage points, with larger effects for adolescents.

keyReferences.title: Asignación Universal por Hijo - Informe de Gestión
keyReferences.source: Administración Nacional de la Seguridad Social

name: Mais Educação
summaryShort: Brazil's extended school day program offering supplementary activities in arts, sports, and academic support to vulnerable students in public schools.
summaryLong: Mais Educação was a federal program that provided funding for extended school day activities in public schools with high concentrations of students from low-income families. Schools could choose from various activity modules including academic tutoring, arts, sports, environmental education, and human rights. The program aimed to improve learning and provide safe spaces for vulnerable students. It was replaced by Novo Mais Educação in 2017 with a greater focus on literacy and math.
objectives: Extend learning time for vulnerable students
Improve academic outcomes through supplementary activities
Provide safe spaces for children during non-school hours
Promote integral education including arts and sports
mechanisms: Federal funding to schools for extended day activities. Schools selected activity modules from a menu of options. Activities delivered by community volunteers and monitors. Target schools based on low IDEB scores and high poverty.
impactSummary: Rigorous evaluations found no positive effect or even negative effects on standardized test scores. The program may have disrupted regular instruction time. Implementation quality varied significantly across schools.

keyOutcomes.effect: Mixed results, some improvement in student engagement

evaluations.title: Impact Evaluation of the Mais Educação Program
evaluations.keyFinding: No positive effects on test scores; possible negative effects in some specifications.

keyReferences.title: Manual Operacional de Educação Integral

name: Carrera Magisterial
summaryShort: Mexico's teacher career ladder program providing salary increases based on a points system incorporating student test scores, professional development, and seniority.
summaryLong: Carrera Magisterial was Mexico's main teacher incentive program, allowing teachers to earn salary increases (up to 200% of base salary) by accumulating points across multiple dimensions: student test scores, professional development, seniority, academic degrees, and peer evaluation. The program was negotiated with the powerful teachers' union (SNTE) and became a major component of teacher compensation. It was replaced by the Servicio Profesional Docente in 2013-2015.
mechanisms: Points-based salary supplement system. Points earned for: student test scores (ENLACE), professional development courses, academic credentials, seniority, peer review. Teachers competed for limited advancement slots. Five salary levels with increasing supplements.
impactSummary: Evaluations found no significant effects on student test scores. Teachers responded to incentives by taking courses and accumulating credentials, but this did not translate to improved student learning. Critics noted gaming of the points system and capture by union interests.

keyOutcomes.effect: Some evidence of negative sorting to disadvantaged schools

evaluations.title: Breaking Ground: Analysis of the Assessment System and Impact of Mexico's Carrera Magisterial Program
evaluations.keyFinding: No significant relationship between participation in Carrera Magisterial and student test score gains.

keyReferences.title: Improving Teaching and Learning through Effective Incentives

name: Inclusion Law
summaryShort: Chile's education reform ending for-profit schools, eliminating co-payments, and prohibiting selective admissions in subsidized schools to reduce segregation.
summaryLong: The Inclusion Law (Ley 20.845) represented a major reform to Chile's market-based education system. The law: (1) ended for-profit status for schools receiving public subsidies, (2) gradually eliminated parental co-payments (copago), and (3) prohibited selective admissions in publicly funded schools. A new centralized lottery system (SAE) was introduced for admissions. The reform aimed to address decades of increasing socioeconomic segregation in Chilean schools.
objectives: Ensure free education in publicly funded schools
Create fair and transparent admissions processes
mechanisms: Prohibition of for-profit schools receiving subsidies (transition period). Gradual elimination of parental co-payments with compensating subsidies. Centralized admissions lottery (SAE) replacing school selection. Increased preferential subsidies for low-income students.
impactSummary: Early evidence suggests the reform has begun to reduce quality gaps between students from different socioeconomic backgrounds. The gap in school quality between poor and non-poor students decreased by 16%. Full effects will take time to materialize as the reform continues implementation.

evaluations.title: Targeted Vouchers, Competition Among Schools, and the Academic Achievement of Poor Students
evaluations.keyFinding: The reform reduced the gap in school quality attending by poor vs. non-poor students by 16%.

keyReferences.title: Models of regulation, education policies, and changes in the education system: a long-term analysis of the Chilean case

name: Literacy Tutoring Program
summaryShort: High-dosage tutoring program in Colombia providing one-on-one literacy instruction to struggling early-grade readers with persistent positive effects.
summaryLong: This structured tutoring program provides intensive one-on-one literacy instruction to first and second-grade students struggling with reading. Trained tutors work with students for 30 minutes daily, following a structured curriculum. The program has been rigorously evaluated through multiple RCTs and has shown persistent positive effects on both literacy and math outcomes, even years after the intervention ended.
objectives: Prevent reading failure in early grades
mechanisms: One-on-one tutoring sessions (30 minutes daily) with trained tutors. Structured curriculum focusing on phonemic awareness, decoding, and comprehension. Targeting students identified as struggling readers through assessments.
impactSummary: RCT evidence shows significant and persistent effects on literacy and numeracy. Effects on reading persist at 0.27 standard deviations one year after the intervention. Notably, the program also improved math achievement despite not directly targeting it.

evaluations.title: Literacy Tutoring Programs: Replication and Persistence of Effects
evaluations.keyFinding: Tutoring effects persist and even grow over time, with spillover effects to untargeted subjects.

keyReferences.title: Tutoring Policy Insights
keyReferences.source: Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab

name: Gratuidad (Free Tuition)
summaryShort: Chile's policy providing free higher education tuition for students from the lowest 60% of household income, covering accredited universities and technical institutes.
summaryLong: Gratuidad is Chile's policy of free tuition for higher education, implemented in 2016. Students from households in the lowest 60% of income distribution attending accredited institutions receive full tuition coverage from the government. The policy built on earlier student aid expansions and responded to massive student protests demanding free education. By 2023, the policy covered approximately 38% of total enrollment.
objectives: Ensure access to higher education regardless of ability to pay
Reduce inequality in access to quality institutions
mechanisms: Government pays tuition directly to accredited institutions for eligible students. Eligibility based on household income (bottom 60%). Students must maintain satisfactory academic progress. Institutions must meet accreditation and other requirements to participate.
coverage: Approximately 38% of higher education enrollment (400,000+ students)
impactSummary: Early evidence suggests the policy has not significantly increased overall enrollment but has shifted enrollment patterns toward higher-quality institutions. The policy may have benefited students who would have enrolled anyway by reducing their debt burden rather than expanding access to new students.

evaluations.title: The Effects of Free Tuition on College Enrollment and Completion
evaluations.keyFinding: Free tuition did not significantly increase enrollment but shifted students toward better institutions.

keyReferences.title: Balance de Gratuidad en Educación Superior

name: Bono de Desarrollo Humano
summaryShort: Ecuador's conditional cash transfer providing monthly payments to poor families, with impacts on cognitive development and school enrollment.
summaryLong: The Bono de Desarrollo Humano began in 1998 as an unconditional transfer (Bono Solidario) and was transformed into a conditional cash transfer in 2003. The program provides monthly payments to families in the two lowest income quintiles, conditional on children's school enrollment and health check-ups. Studies have found positive effects on cognitive development among the poorest beneficiaries.
mechanisms: Monthly cash transfers to eligible households. Conditionalities include school enrollment and health visits. Targeting through proxy means testing. Benefits adjusted periodically for inflation.
impactSummary: Research shows positive effects on cognitive development, particularly for the poorest children. School enrollment effects are positive but modest. The program has been effective at reducing poverty and improving consumption.

evaluations.title: Does Money Matter? The Effects of Cash Transfers on Child Development in Rural Ecuador
evaluations.keyFinding: Cash transfers improved cognitive development among the poorest children, with effects of 0.18 SD on vocabulary.

keyReferences.title: Bono de Desarrollo Humano - Informe Anual
keyReferences.source: Ministerio de Inclusión Económica y Social

name: Bono 10,000 / Bono Vida Mejor
summaryShort: Honduras's conditional cash transfer providing $10,000 Lempiras annually to extremely poor rural families conditional on school attendance and health compliance.
summaryLong: Bono 10,000 (now Bono Vida Mejor) is Honduras's flagship conditional cash transfer program, providing approximately $400 annually to extremely poor households. The program targets rural areas with high poverty rates and conditions transfers on children's school attendance (minimum 80%) and regular health check-ups. Evaluations show significant impacts on school enrollment and child labor reduction.
objectives: Reduce extreme poverty in rural areas
mechanisms: Annual transfer of 10,000 Lempiras (approximately $400) paid in installments. Conditionalities include 80% school attendance and health check-ups. Targeting extremely poor households in rural areas through proxy means testing.
impactSummary: Evaluations found significant positive effects on school enrollment (+12%) and substantial reductions in child labor (-30%). The program has been particularly effective at reaching remote rural communities.

evaluations.title: The heterogeneous impact of conditional cash transfers
evaluations.keyFinding: The program increased enrollment by 12 percentage points and reduced child labor by 30%.

keyReferences.title: Bono Vida Mejor - Informe de Gestión
keyReferences.source: Secretaría de Desarrollo e Inclusión Social

name: Ceará Literacy Program
summaryShort: Ceará state's comprehensive literacy program combining structured materials, teacher training, and municipal incentives that dramatically improved early-grade reading.
summaryLong: PAIC is a comprehensive literacy program implemented by the state of Ceará in northeastern Brazil. The program combines structured pedagogical materials, intensive teacher training, regular student assessments, and strong incentives for municipalities through a results-based allocation of state transfers (ICMS). Ceará transformed from below-average to among Brazil's top-performing states in early literacy, despite being one of the poorest.
objectives: Ensure all children are literate by end of 2nd grade
Improve educational quality in early grades
Build municipal capacity for education management
mechanisms: Structured literacy curriculum and materials. Intensive teacher training and coaching. Regular diagnostic assessments. Strong accountability system with public reporting. Results-based fiscal transfers incentivizing municipal performance. Technical support for municipal education secretariats.
coverage: All 184 municipalities in Ceará state (approximately 1.5 million students)
impactSummary: Ceará's literacy rates improved dramatically, with the state moving from below to above the national average. Studies attribute improvements to the combination of structured pedagogy, teacher support, and strong municipal incentives. The program has been replicated in other Brazilian states.

keyOutcomes.effect: Ceará ranks among top states despite poverty

evaluations.title: The Effects of a Statewide Literacy Reform on School District Management and Student Outcomes
evaluations.journal: World Bank Policy Research Working Paper
evaluations.keyFinding: PAIC improved literacy outcomes by 0.3 SD and effects were sustained over time.

keyReferences.title: PAIC - Programa Alfabetização na Idade Certa
keyReferences.source: Secretaria da Educação do Estado do Ceará

name: Remote Tutoring Program
summaryShort: Low-cost phone-based tutoring intervention during COVID-19 school closures showing significant math learning gains through weekly calls.
summaryLong: During COVID-19 school closures in El Salvador, researchers implemented a low-cost remote tutoring program using basic phone calls. Trained tutors made weekly 15-minute calls to students (or their caregivers) to guide them through grade-appropriate math problems. The intervention demonstrated that simple, scalable approaches can produce meaningful learning gains even without internet access or smartphones.
objectives: Mitigate learning loss during school closures
Provide accessible remote support for disadvantaged students
Support continued learning without internet access
mechanisms: Weekly 15-minute phone calls from trained tutors. Tutors guide students through math problems from workbooks. Low-tech approach requiring only basic phone access. Tutors also provide encouragement and accountability.
impactSummary: The RCT found significant positive effects on math learning (+0.24 SD) with a highly cost-effective delivery model. The intervention was particularly effective for students with lower baseline achievement. The study demonstrates potential for low-tech tutoring at scale.

evaluations.title: Building Resilient Education Systems: Evidence from Large-Scale Randomized Trials in Five Countries
evaluations.keyFinding: Phone-based tutoring improved math scores by 0.24 SD at very low cost, demonstrating scalable remote learning solutions.

keyReferences.title: Acting Now to Protect the Human Capital of Our Children

name: Intercultural Bilingual Education
summaryShort: Mexico's constitutional framework and programs providing education in indigenous languages alongside Spanish to preserve cultural heritage and improve indigenous education outcomes.
summaryLong: Mexico's Intercultural Bilingual Education (EIB) policy provides instruction in 68 indigenous languages alongside Spanish in schools serving indigenous communities. Rooted in constitutional reforms recognizing Mexico as a pluricultural nation, the policy aims to preserve indigenous languages and cultures while ensuring indigenous children gain Spanish proficiency. Implementation has been uneven, with significant challenges in teacher preparation and material development.
objectives: Provide culturally relevant education for indigenous children
Improve educational outcomes for indigenous populations
mechanisms: Bilingual instruction in indigenous language and Spanish. Development of curriculum materials in indigenous languages. Training of bilingual indigenous teachers. Indigenous education subsystem within SEP (DGEI).
impactSummary: Evidence on effectiveness is mixed. When well-implemented, bilingual education can improve learning outcomes for indigenous children. However, implementation challenges including teacher shortages and inadequate materials have limited impact in many areas. Indigenous students continue to have lower educational outcomes than the national average.

evaluations.title: Indigenous Peoples, Poverty, and Human Development in Latin America
evaluations.keyFinding: Bilingual education shows positive effects when implemented with adequate resources and trained teachers.

keyReferences.title: La Educación Obligatoria en México: Informe 2018
keyReferences.source: Instituto Nacional para la Evaluación de la Educación

name: Qali Warma
summaryShort: Peru's national school feeding program providing free breakfast to public school students, with a focus on local food sourcing and nutritional quality.
summaryLong: Qali Warma (meaning 'healthy child' in Quechua) is Peru's national school feeding program, launched in 2012 to replace the previous Programa Nacional de Asistencia Alimentaria (PRONAA). The program provides free school meals to approximately 4.1 million students in public preschools and primary schools. It emphasizes local food sourcing, nutritional adequacy, and community involvement in meal preparation and oversight.
objectives: Ensure food security for school-age children
Improve nutritional status and cognitive function
mechanisms: Provision of school breakfast (and lunch in some areas) to all public school students up to primary level. Food procurement emphasizes local suppliers. School feeding committees oversee quality and delivery. Menus designed to meet nutritional requirements.
impactSummary: Studies show short-term cognitive benefits during school hours but limited long-term effects on academic achievement. Implementation quality varies across regions. Challenges with food quality and storage have been documented.

evaluations.title: Qali Warma: Impact Evaluation of Peru's School Feeding Program
evaluations.keyFinding: Positive effects on short-term cognitive function but no clear effects on learning outcomes.

keyReferences.title: Qali Warma: Memoria Institucional
keyReferences.source: Ministerio de Desarrollo e Inclusión Social

name: De Cero a Siempre
summaryShort: Colombia's national early childhood development policy providing comprehensive services for children from birth to age 5, with focus on most vulnerable populations.
summaryLong: De Cero a Siempre (From Zero to Forever) is Colombia's comprehensive national policy for early childhood development, established as state policy through Law 1804 in 2016. The policy coordinates multiple sectors (health, education, culture, social protection) to ensure comprehensive attention to children from pregnancy through age 5, with priority for children in vulnerable situations. Services include health care, nutrition, early stimulation, and preschool education.
objectives: Coordinate multi-sectoral services for young children
Reduce inequalities in early childhood outcomes
mechanisms: Integration of health, nutrition, education, and protection services. Child development centers (CDI) providing comprehensive care. Home visit programs for vulnerable families. Coordination across government agencies. Priority targeting of vulnerable children.
coverage: Over 1.5 million children in comprehensive care
impactSummary: Evaluations show positive effects on child development indicators, particularly for children in center-based care. Implementation quality varies across regions. The policy has improved coordination across sectors and increased coverage of early childhood services.

keyOutcomes.effect: Positive effects on cognitive and socio-emotional indicators

evaluations.title: The Impact of Early Childhood Development Programs on Child Development in Colombia
evaluations.keyFinding: Center-based programs show positive effects on language and cognitive development.

keyReferences.title: Ley 1804 de 2016 - Política de Estado para el Desarrollo Integral de la Primera Infancia

name: Conectar Igualdad
summaryShort: Argentina's one-laptop-per-child program distributing over 5 million netbooks to secondary students and teachers in public schools.
summaryLong: Conectar Igualdad was Argentina's large-scale digital inclusion program that distributed netbooks to all students and teachers in public secondary schools, special education schools, and teacher training institutes. Launched in 2010, the program distributed over 5 million devices by 2015. The program also included teacher training, digital content development, and infrastructure improvements for connectivity.
objectives: Reduce the digital divide between public and private school students
Integrate technology into teaching and learning
Improve educational quality through digital tools
mechanisms: Distribution of netbooks to all secondary students and teachers in public schools. Teacher training in technology integration. Development of digital educational content. Investment in school connectivity infrastructure.
impactSummary: The program successfully increased access to technology and reduced the digital divide. However, evidence on effects on learning outcomes is limited. Integration of devices into classroom instruction was uneven, with many teachers struggling to effectively use the technology pedagogically.

keyOutcomes.effect: Significant increase, especially for low-income students
Limited evidence of effects on test scores

evaluations.authors: Alderete, María Verónica & Formichella, María Marta
evaluations.title: Efecto de las TIC en el rendimiento educativo
evaluations.keyFinding: Program increased technology access but effects on academic achievement were not clearly demonstrated.

keyReferences.title: Estado del arte sobre la gestión de las políticas de integración de computadoras y dispositivos móviles en los sistemas educativos

name: Comunidades Solidarias
summaryShort: El Salvador's conditional cash transfer program providing incentives for education and health, with evidence showing significant effects when children are exposed from birth.
summaryLong: Comunidades Solidarias (formerly Red Solidaria) is El Salvador's conditional cash transfer program targeting extremely poor rural and urban households. The program provides monthly cash transfers conditional on children's school attendance and regular health check-ups. Research has shown particularly strong effects on school entry when children are exposed to the program from birth.
mechanisms: Monthly cash transfers to eligible households. Conditionalities include school attendance and health visits. Geographic targeting of poorest communities. Both rural and urban components.
impactSummary: Studies show positive effects on school enrollment, with particularly strong impacts (+8 percentage points) when children are exposed from birth. The program has also improved health service utilization and nutritional outcomes.

evaluations.title: Long-Term Effects of Conditional Cash Transfers: Evidence from a Randomized Experiment in Central America
evaluations.keyFinding: Children exposed to CCT from birth had 8 percentage point higher school entry rates.

keyReferences.title: Comunidades Solidarias - Informe de Gestión
keyReferences.source: Fondo de Inversión Social para el Desarrollo Local

name: Progresando con Solidaridad
summaryShort: Dominican Republic's integrated social protection program combining cash transfers with socioeconomic accompaniment services to promote human capital development.
summaryLong: Progresando con Solidaridad (PROSOLI) is the Dominican Republic's main social protection program, created in 2012 by merging the conditional cash transfer program Solidaridad with the Progresando accompaniment program. Beyond cash transfers, PROSOLI provides socioeconomic support services including financial literacy, health promotion, and employment support. The program reaches approximately 900,000 households.
mechanisms: Monthly cash transfers conditional on education and health requirements. Socioeconomic accompaniment through family promoters. Links to complementary social services. SIUBEN targeting system for eligibility.
impactSummary: The program has expanded coverage significantly and linked cash transfers with support services. Evidence on educational impacts is emerging, with the school attendance conditionality expected to affect enrollment and retention.

evaluations.title: Dominican Republic Social Protection Assessment
evaluations.keyFinding: PROSOLI has expanded social protection coverage and improved targeting of the poor.

keyReferences.title: Memoria Institucional 2020

name: Jornada Única
summaryShort: Colombia's extended school day program expanding instructional time from 5 to 8 hours, with early evidence suggesting reduced dropout rates.
summaryLong: Jornada Única is Colombia's policy to extend the school day from approximately 5-6 hours to 8 hours in public schools. Launched in 2014 as part of broader education quality reforms, the policy requires significant infrastructure investment to transition schools from multiple shifts to single full-day operation. Implementation has been gradual, prioritizing schools in disadvantaged areas.
mechanisms: Extension of school day from 5-6 hours to 8 hours. Infrastructure investment for single-shift operation. Additional teaching resources and materials. School meal provision for full-day students.
coverage: Approximately 15% of public schools (target: full coverage)
impactSummary: Early evidence suggests lower dropout rates in schools implementing Jornada Única. Full implementation faces infrastructure constraints. Effects on learning outcomes are still being evaluated as the program expands.

evaluations.title: Evaluación de Jornada Única
evaluations.keyFinding: Schools implementing Jornada Única show lower dropout rates and improved school climate.

keyReferences.title: Plan de Implementación de la Jornada Única
keyReferences.source: Ministerio de Educación Nacional de Colombia

name: Educación Intercultural Bilingüe
summaryShort: Peru's intercultural bilingual education policy serving indigenous communities in 47 languages, with teacher training through PROEIB Andes.
summaryLong: Peru's Intercultural Bilingual Education (EIB) policy provides education in 47 indigenous languages alongside Spanish to children in indigenous communities. The policy emphasizes culturally relevant pedagogy and has developed curriculum materials in multiple languages. Teacher training is supported through programs like PROEIB Andes (Programa de Formación en Educación Intercultural Bilingüe para los Países Andinos).
objectives: Provide quality education in indigenous languages
Preserve and value indigenous cultures and languages
Achieve Spanish proficiency alongside native language
Improve educational outcomes for indigenous children
mechanisms: Instruction in indigenous language (L1) and Spanish (L2). Development of curriculum and materials in indigenous languages. Training of bilingual indigenous teachers through PROEIB Andes and national programs. Community participation in education planning.
impactSummary: The policy has expanded coverage of bilingual education and developed materials in numerous languages. Teacher training programs have improved capacity. However, quality of implementation varies significantly, and learning gaps between indigenous and non-indigenous students persist.

evaluations.title: Reaching the Unreached: Indigenous Intercultural Bilingual Education in Latin America
evaluations.keyFinding: Peru's EIB policy has expanded access but implementation quality remains a challenge.

keyReferences.title: Política Sectorial de Educación Intercultural Bilingüe

name: Programa de Alimentación Escolar
summaryShort: Colombia's national school feeding program, one of Latin America's oldest, providing meals to millions of students with decentralized implementation.
summaryLong: Colombia's School Feeding Program (PAE) is one of the oldest in Latin America, dating back to 1941. The program provides school meals to students in public schools, with implementation managed at the departmental and municipal level. Coverage has expanded significantly in recent decades, though challenges with implementation quality, food safety, and corruption have affected the program.
objectives: Ensure food security for school-age children
mechanisms: School meal provision managed by departments and municipalities. National guidelines on nutritional requirements. Mix of direct provision and contracted operators. Targeting prioritizes poorest areas and most vulnerable students.
impactSummary: The program has expanded coverage significantly but faces implementation challenges. Corruption scandals and quality issues have affected the program in some areas. Rigorous impact evaluations are limited.

evaluations.title: Auditoría al Programa de Alimentación Escolar
evaluations.keyFinding: Implementation quality varies significantly across departments, with challenges in oversight and quality control.

keyReferences.title: Lineamientos Técnicos del Programa de Alimentación Escolar

name: Teacher Performance Evaluation
summaryShort: Chile's comprehensive teacher evaluation system using portfolios, peer assessment, and self-evaluation to inform professional development and career advancement.
summaryLong: Chile's Teacher Performance Evaluation system assesses public school teachers through multiple instruments: portfolio with lesson plans and video recordings, peer evaluation, supervisor assessment, and self-evaluation. Results classify teachers into four performance levels and inform career advancement opportunities and professional development needs. The system has evolved over time and is connected to the teacher career ladder (Carrera Docente).
mechanisms: Multi-instrument evaluation including portfolio, peer assessment, supervisor evaluation, and self-assessment. Four-level performance classification (Distinguished, Competent, Basic, Unsatisfactory). Links to professional development and career advancement. Mandatory for public school teachers.
impactSummary: The evaluation system provides systematic feedback and identifies teachers needing support. Research shows correlation between evaluation results and student outcomes. The system has been criticized for heavy documentation burden and limited support for struggling teachers.

keyOutcomes.effect: Rare, most struggling teachers receive support

evaluations.title: Teacher Performance and Student Learning: Evidence from Chile's Docentemás Program
evaluations.keyFinding: Teacher evaluation results are correlated with student achievement gains.

keyReferences.title: Evaluación Docente: Marco para la Buena Enseñanza
keyReferences.source: Centro de Perfeccionamiento, Experimentación e Investigaciones Pedagógicas

name: Teacher Reform Law
summaryShort: Ecuador's comprehensive education law that reformed teacher careers, introduced mandatory evaluations, and significantly changed the teaching workforce composition.
summaryLong: Ecuador's 2009 education reform introduced major changes to the teaching profession through the Ley Orgánica de Educación Intercultural (LOEI). The reform established mandatory teacher evaluations, new career structure, and improved working conditions. However, the reform also triggered massive retirements (40,000 teachers) and resulted in a much younger, less experienced teaching workforce by 2016.
mechanisms: Mandatory teacher evaluations with consequences. New career ladder structure. Changes to retirement benefits triggering early retirements. Updated teacher certification requirements. Salary adjustments linked to performance.
impactSummary: The reform significantly changed the teaching workforce, with 40,000 retirements and a shift to younger teachers. By 2016, 50% of teachers had fewer than 5 years of experience. Long-term effects on teaching quality and student outcomes are still being evaluated.

evaluations.title: Teacher Workforce Changes Following Ecuador's Education Reform
evaluations.keyFinding: Reform caused dramatic workforce turnover, with 40,000 retirements and significant youth-ification of the teaching force.

keyReferences.title: Carrera Educativa en Ecuador

name: Generación E
summaryShort: Colombia's reformed higher education access program replacing Ser Pilo Paga with broader coverage and focus on public universities.
summaryLong: Generación E replaced the Ser Pilo Paga program in 2019, shifting the model from full coverage at any accredited university (often private) to a program with three components: Equity (free tuition at public universities), Excellence (merit-based support for top students), and Equity in Access. The program aims to expand access while directing more funding to public institutions.
mechanisms: Three-component structure: Equity (gratuity at public universities for lower-income students), Excellence (full support for top performers), Access (credit support). Shift in funding toward public universities. Living cost support for eligible students.
impactSummary: The program has expanded coverage significantly compared to Ser Pilo Paga but with different targeting. Early evidence on outcomes is still being collected. Debates continue about the trade-offs between the SPP and Generación E models.

keyOutcomes.effect: Ongoing debate on equity vs. excellence trade-offs

evaluations.title: Generación E: Balance de Implementación
evaluations.keyFinding: Program has expanded coverage but rigorous impact evaluation is pending.

keyReferences.title: Comparing Ser Pilo Paga and Generación E
keyReferences.source: Universidad de los Andes Policy Brief

name: Teacher Standards and Wage Reform
summaryShort: Dominican Republic's teacher reform raising entry standards and increasing real teacher wages by 31% from 2012-2016.
summaryLong: As part of broader education reforms following the 4% of GDP education spending commitment, the Dominican Republic implemented significant teacher reforms. These included raising teacher certification standards, introducing new evaluations, and substantially increasing teacher salaries. Real teacher wages increased by 31% between 2012 and 2016, making teaching a more attractive profession.
mechanisms: Increased entry requirements for teacher certification. New evaluation processes. Significant salary increases (31% real wage increase 2012-2016). Professional development investments. Performance-linked compensation elements.
impactSummary: The reforms significantly improved teacher compensation and raised entry standards. Early evidence suggests improved teacher quality indicators and increased attractiveness of the profession. Long-term effects on student learning are being monitored.

evaluations.title: Dominican Republic Education Sector Review
evaluations.keyFinding: Teacher wage reforms have improved the attractiveness of teaching and raised professional standards.

keyReferences.title: Pacto Nacional para la Reforma Educativa - Informe de Avances
keyReferences.source: Ministerio de Educación de la República Dominicana

name: Ley de Reforma Magisterial
summaryShort: Peru's comprehensive teacher career reform establishing meritocratic evaluation systems and standardized career progression.
summaryLong: Peru's Teacher Career Reform Law (Ley de Reforma Magisterial, Law 29944) established a unified meritocratic career system for teachers. The reform introduced standardized evaluations for hiring, permanence, and promotion. Teachers must pass evaluations to advance in the career ladder, with salary implications. The reform faced significant opposition from teachers' unions but was implemented with government support.
mechanisms: Unified career ladder replacing multiple previous systems. Competitive examinations for hiring. Periodic performance evaluations. Salary scales linked to career level. Consequences for consistently poor performance.
impactSummary: The reform unified Peru's fragmented teacher career systems and introduced systematic evaluation. Implementation has been challenging, with union opposition and capacity constraints. Effects on teaching quality and student outcomes are still being assessed.

keyOutcomes.effect: Single system replaced multiple previous structures

evaluations.title: Teacher Career Reforms in Latin America
evaluations.keyFinding: Peru's reform successfully unified the career system but faces ongoing implementation challenges.

keyReferences.title: Ley de Reforma Magisterial - Balance de Implementación

name: Indigenous Education Reform
nameLocal: Ley de la Educación Avelino Siñani - Elizardo Pérez
summaryShort: Bolivia's indigenous-centered education reform emphasizing community participation, bilingual instruction, and decolonization of education.
summaryLong: Bolivia has undertaken significant education reforms centered on indigenous rights and intercultural education, beginning with the 1994 Education Reform and transformed under the 2010 Avelino Siñani - Elizardo Pérez Law. The current framework emphasizes intra-cultural, intercultural, and plurilingual education, with strong community and indigenous participation in educational governance. The reform is unique in Latin America for its emphasis on decolonization and indigenous epistemologies.
objectives: Recognize and value indigenous knowledge systems
mechanisms: Mandatory instruction in indigenous languages. Community education councils (CEPOs) for indigenous participation. Curriculum incorporating indigenous knowledge. Training of indigenous and intercultural teachers. Decolonization as cross-cutting theme.
coverage: All public schools, with special emphasis on indigenous communities
impactSummary: The reforms have significantly expanded indigenous participation in educational governance and increased use of indigenous languages in schools. Implementation varies by region. Systematic evaluation of learning outcomes is limited.

evaluations.title: La EIB en Bolivia
evaluations.keyFinding: Bolivia's bottom-up approach to indigenous education reform has achieved significant community engagement.

keyReferences.title: Interculturalidad, educación y política en América Latina

name: Bilingual Education System
summaryShort: Ecuador's separate educational track providing instruction in indigenous languages for Kichwa, Shuar, and other indigenous nationalities.
summaryLong: Ecuador established a parallel intercultural bilingual education system (SEIB) in 1988, providing a separate administrative structure for indigenous education. The system serves primarily Kichwa and Shuar-speaking communities but includes instruction in other indigenous languages. The SEIB has its own curriculum, teacher training, and governance structures, though coordination with the mainstream system has varied over time.
objectives: Achieve educational quality for indigenous students
mechanisms: Separate administrative structure for indigenous education. Curriculum in indigenous languages (primarily Kichwa, Shuar). Teacher training specific to intercultural bilingual education. Community participation in school governance.
impactSummary: The system has provided education in indigenous languages and maintained cultural transmission. However, quality indicators often lag behind the mainstream system. Debates continue about the benefits and drawbacks of a separate track versus integration.

evaluations.title: Resultados Educativos: Sistema de Educación Intercultural Bilingüe
evaluations.keyFinding: SEIB students show lower average test scores but the gap has narrowed in recent years.

keyReferences.title: La Educación Intercultural Bilingüe en Ecuador

name: Novo Mais Educação
summaryShort: Reformed version of Brazil's extended day program with greater focus on literacy and math tutoring in early grades.
summaryLong: Novo Mais Educação was launched in 2017 to replace the original Mais Educação program with a greater focus on foundational literacy and math skills. The reformed program emphasized structured tutoring activities in Portuguese and mathematics rather than the broader menu of cultural and sports activities in the original version. Initial evaluations suggested more positive effects than the predecessor, particularly in early grades.
objectives: Reduce learning deficits in early grades
More focused use of extended time
mechanisms: Extended school day focused on literacy and math tutoring. Structured pedagogical materials for tutoring activities. Training for tutors (mediadores and facilitadores). Priority to schools with lowest IDEB scores.
impactSummary: Early evaluations suggest more positive effects than the original Mais Educação, particularly for early-grade literacy. The program was discontinued in 2019 amid broader education policy changes. Limited time for comprehensive impact assessment.

keyOutcomes.effect: Shifted from diverse activities to academic support

evaluations.title: Novo Mais Educação - Relatório de Avaliação
evaluations.keyFinding: Program showed more promising results than predecessor, particularly in early-grade literacy.

keyReferences.title: From Mais Educação to Novo Mais Educação: Lessons from Brazil's Extended Day Programs

name: Volunteer Literacy Tutoring
summaryShort: Chile's volunteer-based tutoring programs using trained community members to provide one-on-one reading support for struggling early-grade students.
summaryLong: Various volunteer tutoring programs in Chile have provided one-on-one reading support to struggling students in early grades. These programs typically recruit and train university students, retirees, or other community volunteers to work with children identified as behind in reading. Research shows positive effects on literacy and secondary outcomes like school completion.
mechanisms: One-on-one tutoring sessions (typically 30-45 minutes, 2-3 times weekly). Trained volunteer tutors (often university students). Structured literacy activities and materials. Targeting students identified through school assessments.
impactSummary: Studies show positive effects on reading achievement and downstream outcomes including reduced dropout and improved graduation rates. Volunteer tutoring provides cost-effective early intervention. Program quality depends on volunteer training and support.

keyOutcomes.effect: Reduced dropout rates for tutored students

evaluations.title: The Effect of a Tutoring Program on the School Outcomes of Chilean Students
evaluations.keyFinding: Tutoring reduced dropout and improved high school graduation rates.

keyReferences.title: Volunteer Tutoring for Reading: Evidence from Chile

name: Tekoporã
summaryShort: Paraguay's largest conditional cash transfer program targeting extreme poverty through education and health conditionalities.
summaryLong: Tekoporã is Paraguay's flagship CCT program launched in 2005, targeting extreme poor households in the poorest districts. The program provides cash transfers conditional on school attendance, regular health center visits, and updated immunizations. It includes a family support initiative to increase productive potential and social participation. The program aims to break the intergenerational cycle of poverty through human capital investments.
objectives: Reduce extreme poverty through direct cash transfers
Increase school attendance among poor children
Improve health outcomes through preventive care
mechanisms: Cash transfers to households in extreme poverty conditional on children's school attendance and regular health center visits. Includes family support services and social accountability mechanisms through Citizen Report Cards and Community Score Cards implemented 2015-2019.
impactSummary: Impact evaluation found positive effects on income, consumption, poverty reduction, and school attendance (+5-8%). However, the program has not succeeded in reducing child labor or increasing immunization rates. Positive effects on agricultural investment and savings were observed.

keyOutcomes.effect: +5-8 percentage points, especially for boys and older children

evaluations.title: Achievements and Shortfalls of Conditional Cash Transfers: Impact Evaluation of Paraguay's Tekoporã Programme
evaluations.keyFinding: Positive impacts on school attendance and consumption, but no effect on child labor or immunization.

keyReferences.title: Supporting Social Accountability for Better Outcomes: Paraguay's Tekoporã CCT Program

name: Programa de Alimentación Escolar
summaryShort: Guatemala's national school feeding program providing meals based on the human right to food, with cultural and ethnic relevance.
summaryLong: Guatemala's school feeding program provides nutritious meals to students in public schools, with emphasis on cultural, social, and ethnic relevance. The country has among the highest malnutrition rates in Latin America, with 74.5% literacy rate (lowest in Central America) and up to 60% illiteracy in indigenous populations. The program is part of the School Meals Coalition, sharing best practices internationally.
objectives: Improve nutrition and health of schoolchildren
Reduce dropout rates, especially among girls
mechanisms: Daily meals provided at public schools with emphasis on locally-sourced, culturally appropriate foods. Program linked to human right to food framework.
coverage: Approximately 2.5 million students in public schools
impactSummary: Limited rigorous evaluation exists. International evidence suggests school meals can improve attendance and short-term cognitive outcomes, but Guatemala-specific impact studies are scarce. UNICEF recommends strengthening education management information systems to produce relevant data on program effectiveness.

keyOutcomes.effect: Reaches majority of public primary schools

keyReferences.title: All Children Learn in Guatemala
Guatemala Country Profile

name: Digital Transformation Policy
summaryShort: Guatemala's 2025-2035 strategic roadmap to modernize public education through connectivity, devices, and digital skills training.
summaryLong: Launched in June 2025, Guatemala's Digital Transformation Policy aims to modernize the public education system serving 3.5 million students across 36,000 schools. The roadmap focuses on improving connectivity, distributing devices, upgrading technological infrastructure, and strengthening digital skills for teachers and students. By 2027, the government targets 80% coverage in secondary schools with connectivity and device provision.
objectives: Bridge the digital divide in education by 2035
Achieve 80% connectivity in secondary schools by 2027
Strengthen digital skills for teachers and students
mechanisms: Multi-year implementation of connectivity infrastructure, device distribution to students and teachers, digital literacy training programs, and technology integration in curriculum.
impactSummary: Program recently launched in 2025. No evaluation evidence yet available. Represents significant research opportunity to assess digital inclusion interventions in a high-poverty, multilingual context with large indigenous population.

keyReferences.title: Digital Transformation Policy Launch

name: Costa Rica Results in Education
summaryShort: World Bank-supported project to improve foundational learning, digital competencies, and employability skills for one million Costa Rican students.
summaryLong: Approved in December 2024, this World Bank-funded project aims to transform Costa Rica's education system, which has faced challenges including declining PISA scores and learning losses from COVID-19. The project benefits one million students (51% girls) in preschool through secondary education, focusing on foundational learning, digital competencies, and employability skills. Costa Rica's education system, while historically strong, now faces quality challenges as economic demands change.
mechanisms: Comprehensive education reform including curriculum updates, teacher training, digital infrastructure, and learning assessment improvements. Uses results-based financing tied to achievement of educational outcomes.
coverage: 1 million students (51% girls) in public preschool, primary, and secondary education
impactSummary: Project approved December 2024. No evaluation evidence yet. Costa Rica eliminated standardized national exams in 2018, creating data gaps on student achievement. New assessment tools being developed. Significant research opportunity for PhD students.

keyReferences.title: World Bank Approves Funding to Transform Education in Costa Rica

name: Beca Universal
summaryShort: Panama's universal scholarship providing annual payments to primary and secondary students conditional on academic performance and attendance.
summaryLong: Beca Universal is Panama's scholarship program providing financial support to students in primary, premedia, and media (secondary) education. Managed by IFARHU (Institute for Training and Development of Human Resources), the program provides between B/.270 and B/.450 annually to cover expenses like uniforms, books, school supplies, and transportation. Benefits are conditional on passing studies and maintaining adequate attendance and conduct.
mechanisms: Annual cash transfers paid in three installments, varying by education level: elementary students receive $270/year, middle school $360/year, high school $450/year. Payments conditional on passing grades and attendance. Recent reforms (2024) include digital payment via Clave Social card.
impactSummary: No rigorous impact evaluation identified. Program has broad coverage but lacks evidence on effects on attendance, retention, or learning outcomes. Represents significant research opportunity given scale and universal nature of the intervention.

keyReferences.title: Reform to Beca Universal Program

name: PSUGO
nameLocal: Programme de Scolarisation Universelle Gratuite et Obligatoire
summaryShort: Haiti's universal free education program (2011-2017) that financed school fees for over 60% of primary students before being discontinued.
summaryLong: PSUGO was Haiti's ambitious program to provide universal, free, and compulsory education following the 2010 earthquake. At its peak (2011-2014), PSUGO and related programs financed school fees for over 60% of all primary students. However, the program faced severe implementation challenges including corruption allegations, inadequate payments to schools, late payments, and undelivered supplies. When discontinued in 2017, an estimated 700,000 students were at risk of losing school access.
mechanisms: Government payments to schools (both public and private) to waive student fees. Private schools received six times the amount paid to public schools. Funded through National Education Fund (FNE).
coverage: Over 60% of primary students at peak (approximately 1.4 million)
impactSummary: Program expansion increased access but implementation failures undermined effectiveness. Investigations revealed corruption, inadequate and delayed payments, and undelivered supplies. Discontinuation in 2017 left 700,000 students at risk. Haiti's education system remains 80% private, creating ongoing access barriers.

evaluations.title: Investigation of PSUGO Implementation
evaluations.keyFinding: Revealed corruption, inadequate payments, delayed disbursements, and undelivered school supplies.

keyReferences.title: Education for All in Haiti

name: Misiones Educativas (Robinson, Ribas, Sucre)
summaryShort: Venezuela's educational missions providing adult literacy (Robinson), secondary completion (Ribas), and higher education access (Sucre).
summaryLong: The Bolivarian Educational Missions emerged under President Hugo Chávez in 2003 with Cuban support: Misión Robinson I and II for adult literacy, Misión Ribas for secondary education completion, and Misión Sucre for higher education access. The programs created a parallel educational system outside traditional institutions, with students progressing from Robinson to Ribas to Sucre or the Bolivarian University. While 79% of surveyed Venezuelans agreed the missions increased educational levels, efficiency studies found programs were 'close to inefficient.'
objectives: Enable adults to complete secondary education (Ribas)
mechanisms: Parallel educational system with Cuban pedagogical support. Scholarships provided to students. Community-based 'university villages' and learning environments established. Competency-based evaluation focused on knowing, doing, being, and coexisting.
coverage: Millions of beneficiaries across three programs; 72 university villages constructed
impactSummary: Survey data shows high public approval (79% agreed missions increased educational levels). However, a 2013-2015 efficiency study found all three missions rated 'almost inefficient to close to inefficient' (efficiency scores 0.25-0.35). Critics note the missions created a closed educational circuit and parallel institutionality with ideological orientation.

evaluations.title: Eficiencia de las Misiones Sociales de Venezuela
evaluations.keyFinding: Educational missions obtained efficiency thresholds classified as 'almost inefficient to close to inefficient.'

keyReferences.title: Las misiones educativas: ¿política pública para la inclusión o estrategia para el clientelismo político?
keyReferences.source: Revista Venezolana de Análisis de Coyuntura

name: Becas Benito Juárez
nameLocal: Becas para el Bienestar Benito Juárez
summaryShort: Mexico's flagship scholarship program replacing Prospera, providing cash transfers to over 13 million students from primary through higher education.
summaryLong: The Benito Juárez Scholarships for Well-being replaced the educational components of the PROSPERA program in 2019. The program has three components: Primary Education Scholarships (9.2M beneficiaries), Universal Secondary Education Scholarships (3.6M beneficiaries), and Youth Writing the Future for higher education (380K beneficiaries). Unlike Prospera, payments are per family rather than per student, and health/nutrition conditionalities were removed.
objectives: Reduce economic barriers for vulnerable families
mechanisms: Cash transfers to families with children in school. Geographic targeting based on Social Lag Index and Marginalization Index. Priority given to indigenous areas and high-marginalization zones. No health or nutrition conditionalities (unlike predecessor Prospera).
coverage: Over 13 million beneficiaries across three program components
impactSummary: Design evaluations conducted (2019-2020) but limited impact evidence. CONEVAL raised concerns that family-based (vs. per-student) payments may negatively affect attendance, particularly for girls. The removal of health conditionalities and shift in payment structure represent significant departures from the well-evaluated Prospera model that warrant investigation.

evaluations.title: Evaluación de Diseño con Trabajo de Campo del Programa Becas Benito Juárez
evaluations.keyFinding: Per-family payments (vs. per-student) may have opposite effects on attendance for other household members.

keyReferences.title: Benito Juárez Scholarships Program Profile

name: Pé-de-Meia
summaryShort: Brazil's 2024 high school scholarship program providing up to R$9,200 over three years to reduce dropout and encourage graduation.
summaryLong: Pé-de-Meia was established by Law 14,818 in January 2024 to combat high school dropout in Brazil. The program provides monthly incentives plus annual bonuses to public high school students from low-income families (registered in CadÚnico and Bolsa Família). Students can receive up to R$5,600 during high school, with an additional R$3,000 locked savings released upon graduation. In 2024, the program reached 3.9 million students (54% of public secondary enrollment).
objectives: Encourage high school completion through savings incentive
mechanisms: Monthly payments conditional on 80% attendance and academic approval. Annual bonus of R$1,000 for passing to next grade. Locked savings account released only upon high school completion. Automatic enrollment for eligible CadÚnico/Bolsa Família families.
coverage: 3.9 million students in 2024 (54% of public secondary enrollment); target of 5 million by 2026
impactSummary: Early Ministry of Education data (2024) indicates 15% reduction in dropout rates in served regions and 25% increase in attendance in some schools, particularly in the Northeast. Enem participation increased 18%. Program too new for rigorous evaluation. Significant research opportunity for PhD students.

keyReferences.title: Pé-de-Meia Program Profile

name: Beca 18
nameLocal: Programa Nacional de Becas y Crédito Educativo - Beca 18
summaryShort: Peru's comprehensive higher education scholarship covering full tuition and living expenses for students from the poorest quintiles.
summaryLong: Beca 18 is Peru's major public scholarship program targeting students from the bottom two poverty quintiles, where indigenous groups are overrepresented. The scholarship covers full tuition, living expenses, books, moving costs, laptop, health insurance, and academic tutoring. Up to 5,000 students per year access private education in major cities through the program. While increasing access, the program faces challenges with discrimination, retention, and integration of indigenous and rural students.
objectives: Reduce socioeconomic gap in higher education access
Enable students from poorest quintiles to attend quality universities
Increase human capital in underserved regions
