mechanisms: Comprehensive scholarship covering tuition plus full living expenses, targeting students from bottom two poverty quintiles. Includes academic support services and tutoring. Students can attend private universities in major cities.
coverage: Up to 5,000 new students annually; thousands of continuing students
impactSummary: Research shows positive effects on academic performance and salary returns. Studies find spillover effects on younger students' aspirations. However, 28% of recipients report discrimination (78% citing scholarship status as reason). Challenges include retention of indigenous students, language barriers, and integration difficulties.

keyOutcomes.effect: Scholarship recipients achieve higher grades than non-recipients
28% of recipients report discrimination on campus

evaluations.title: Salary Returns of Higher Education among Beca 18 Beneficiaries
evaluations.keyFinding: University completion leads to greater economic benefits, influenced by gender, location, and field of study.

evaluations.title: Aspirations and Academic Achievement: The Spillover Effects of Beca 18
evaluations.keyFinding: Program has relevant spillover effects on educational aspirations of younger students.

keyReferences.title: Beca 18 Beneficiary Survey

name: Progresar
summaryShort: Argentina's scholarship program supporting 1.4 million vulnerable young people to complete secondary and higher education.
summaryLong: Progresar was created in 2014 to encourage educational completion among young Argentines facing employment deficits. The program provides scholarships at obligatory (secondary), superior (higher education), and vocational training levels. With World Bank support, Progresar reaches 1.4 million vulnerable young people. In Argentina, only half of students finish secondary on time (one-third for vulnerable students), and only 29% of higher education entrants graduate.
mechanisms: Monthly scholarships to young people from vulnerable households, conditional on enrollment and academic progress. Different tracks for obligatory education, higher education (including nursing), and vocational training. Online application system.
coverage: 1.4 million vulnerable young people; 800,000+ accessed benefits in 2024
impactSummary: Research using panel data with fixed effects found the program increases probability of transition to quality (formal) employment by 4.1 percentage points, mainly for those coming from inactivity. Effect stronger for women (6.2 pp for formal employment). Limited evidence on educational outcomes directly.

evaluations.title: Effects of Argentine Students' Support Program on Labor Transitions and Job Quality
evaluations.keyFinding: Program increases probability of transition to formal employment, especially for women.

keyReferences.title: Argentina: Improving Inclusion in Secondary and Higher Education

name: Nueva Educación Pública
summaryShort: Chile's comprehensive reform transferring public schools from municipalities to new Local Education Services (SLEP), the most significant education policy in 40 years.
summaryLong: The Nueva Educación Pública (Law 21.040) represents Chile's most significant state education policy in 40 years, transferring public schools from municipal control to 70 new Servicios Locales de Educación Pública (SLEP). By 2024, 15 SLEP are fully operational and 21 in installation, covering 224,000 students and 1,000 schools. The reform responds to decades of educational inequality under the voucher system and demands from student movements culminating in the 2019 social uprising.
objectives: Strengthen public education as a state priority
Create coherent governance structure for public schools
mechanisms: Transfer of schools from 345 municipalities to 70 new SLEP administered by Dirección de Educación Pública. Multi-year installation process with standards for anticipation, operation, transfer, and full regime phases.
coverage: 224,000+ students in 1,000+ establishments (as of 2024); ultimately all public schools
impactSummary: External evaluation by Universidad de Chile (2024) identified implementation challenges including financing tensions, weak inter-institutional collaboration, and limited DEP capacity. Dropout rates fell 20% (1.9% to 1.5%) between 2022-2024. Infrastructure investment of $26.6 billion CLP in 2024. Reform represents major research opportunity on education governance.

evaluations.title: Evaluación externa de la política de Nueva Educación Pública
evaluations.keyFinding: Identified implementation challenges including financing tensions and weak institutional collaboration, with recommendations for improvement.

keyReferences.title: Análisis Nueva Educación Pública en Chile

name: República Digital Educación
summaryShort: Dominican Republic's initiative to bridge the digital divide through technology access, infrastructure, and digital skills development.
summaryLong: República Digital Educación, launched in 2016, aims to provide technology access for all citizens while ensuring gender equity and social inclusion. The program focuses on bridging the digital divide for vulnerable populations—low-income families, rural communities, and those with limited education—through technology infrastructure, internet access, and community technology centers. The initiative is part of broader education reforms under the National Pact for Education Reform 2014-2030.
objectives: Bridge the digital divide in education
Provide technology access for vulnerable populations
Develop digital skills for teachers and students
mechanisms: Device distribution, internet connectivity expansion, teacher digital training, and community technology centers. Integrated with broader education assessment reforms including development of national learning assessments.
coverage: Public primary and secondary schools nationwide
impactSummary: Limited rigorous evaluation available. COVID-19 revealed significant regional disparities in digital access despite program. World Bank technical support helped develop learning assessment systems. Research opportunity exists to evaluate digital inclusion effects, particularly given revealed inequalities during pandemic remote learning.

keyReferences.title: How to Reform Learning Assessment Systems: Lessons from the Dominican Republic
COVID-19 Digital Learning Strategies in the Dominican Republic

name: Yo, Sí Puedo Literacy Campaign
nameLocal: Campaña de Alfabetización Yo, Sí Puedo
summaryShort: Cuba-method literacy campaign launched in 2007 building on Nicaragua's 1980 Literacy Crusade tradition.
summaryLong: In 2007, after Daniel Ortega's return to the presidency, Nicaragua launched a new literacy campaign based on Cuba's 'Yo, sí puedo' (Yes, I can) method. This builds on the legacy of the famous 1980 Nicaraguan Literacy Campaign, which reduced illiteracy from 50% to 23% using student volunteer teachers and won UNESCO's Literacy Award. However, follow-up studies found literacy gains eroded over time, particularly among women, and many 'graduates' who retained skills had prior formal schooling.
objectives: Build on legacy of 1980 Literacy Crusade
mechanisms: Cuban 'Yo, sí puedo' audiovisual literacy method. Community-based instruction. Historical context: 1980 campaign used 60,000 youth volunteers trained in two-week courses for five-month campaign.
impactSummary: The 1980 campaign achieved dramatic short-term results (illiteracy from 50% to 23%) but 1994 follow-up found significant skill erosion, especially among women. By end of Sandinista era, literacy rates had declined from 1980 levels. Limited rigorous evaluation of post-2007 campaign. Historical campaigns criticized for political/ideological content in materials.

keyOutcomes.effect: Significant literacy loss, especially among women without prior schooling

evaluations.title: Follow-up Study of 1980 Literacy Campaign
evaluations.keyFinding: A decade later, significant portion of women graduates no longer able to read or write; those who could mostly had prior formal schooling.

keyReferences.title: Nicaragua's Literacy Campaign

name: Cuban Universal Education System
summaryShort: Cuba's comprehensive public education system that achieved near-universal literacy and topped regional assessments, though facing recent challenges.
summaryLong: Cuba's education system, transformed after the 1961 Literacy Campaign, achieved remarkable outcomes: universal enrollment, near-universal adult literacy, and top regional performance in mathematics and science. Cuba was the only LAC country to meet all UNESCO Education for All 2000-2015 goals. The system emphasizes teacher training as lifelong process, with 75-97% of teachers holding university degrees. However, recent challenges include teacher shortages, young people preferring tourism jobs, and declining university enrollment.
objectives: Provide universal free education at all levels
Maintain high teacher quality through continuous training
Achieve educational equity across regions and populations
mechanisms: Centralized public education system with intensive pre-service and in-service teacher training. Fifteen pedagogical institutes provide formal teacher preparation. All teachers certified with majority holding university degrees. Continuous assessment and participatory teacher evaluation process.
coverage: Universal coverage from primary through higher education
impactSummary: Cuba achieved exceptional results in regional assessments (first in LAC for math/science at all grade levels) and met all UNESCO EFA goals. The 1961 literacy campaign reduced illiteracy from 23% to 3.9% in one year. However, recent data shows declining higher education enrollment (89,560 degrees in 2012-13 vs. 23,478 in 2016-17) and teacher shortages as economic incentives favor tourism sector.

keyOutcomes.effect: Illiteracy reduced from 23% to 3.9% in one year
First in LAC for math and science at all grade levels

evaluations.title: The Cuban Education System: Lessons and Dilemmas
evaluations.keyFinding: Universal enrollment, high literacy, and strong scientific training, but facing economic and ideological challenges.

keyReferences.title: The Cuban Education System: Lessons and Dilemmas
